label: BODY

text: action on behalf of the debtor.  For the reasons stated in In re Stanwich Financial Services
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: not appeal that decision.

text: ORDER DENYING DEFENDANTS’ MOTION TO DISMISS
label: HH1

text: Alan H.W. Shiff, United States Bankruptcy Judge:
label: BODY

text: Stanwich Financial Services Corp. commenced this chapter 11 case on June 25,
label: BODY

text: 2001.   On May 3, 2002, the Official Committee of Unsecured Creditors (the “Committee”),
label: BODY

text: filed the instant adversary proceeding on behalf of the bankruptcy estate to recover certain
label: BODY

text: prepetition transfers to the defendants pursuant to an April 16, 2002 court approved
label: BODY

text: stipulation with the debtor.  On October 1, 2002, the Pardee and Sutro defendants
label: BODY

text: (hereafter the “movants”) challenged the standing of the Committee to assert this cause of
label: BODY

text: action.   On December 27, 2002, the court ruled in favor of the Committee.  See In re
label: BODY

text: Stanwich Financial Services Corp., 288 B.R. 24, 26, 2002 Bankr. LEXIS 1479, *6 (Bankr.
label: BODY

text: On November 14 and 19, 2002, the movants filed the instant motions to dismiss
label: BODY

text: Counts I and II of  the complaint under Rule 12(b)(6) F.R.Civ.P., and Count VIII of the
label: BODY

text: complaint under Rule 12(b)(1), F.R.Civ.P., which are made applicable here by Rule
label: BODY

text: 7012(b), F.R.Bankr.P.1
label: BODY

text: 2Rule 12 (b) provides, in pertinent part: “Defenses and Objections . . .   the following
label: BODY

text: defenses may at the option of the pleader be made by motion: (1) lack of jurisdiction over
label: BODY

text: the subject matter . . . (6) failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted . . . .”
label: BODY

text: Standard for dismissal under 12(b)(1) and (6)
label: BODY

text: In considering  a motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(1) and (6),2 courts “must accept
label: BODY

text: the material facts alleged in the complaint as true and construe all inferences in the
label: BODY

text: plaintiff’s favor.”   Hirsch v. Arthur Andersen & Co., 72 F.3d 1085, 1088 (2nd Cir.1995);
label: BODY

text: Grant v. Wallignford Board of Education, 69 F.3d 669, 672 (2nd Cir. 1995).  As the United
label: BODY

text: States Supreme Court has instructed, “a court may dismiss a complaint only if it is clear
label: BODY

text: that no relief could be granted under any set of facts that could be proved consistent with
label: BODY

text: the allegations.”  Swierkiewicz v. Sorema N.A., 534 U.S. 506, 507 (2002), citing Hishon v.
label: BODY

text: King & Spalding, 467 U.S. 69, 73 (1984).
label: BODY

text: Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss Counts I and II
label: HH3

text: Counts I and II seek the avoidance of transfers to the movants on the basis that
label: BODY

text: they engaged in intentional and constructive fraud as defined by Rhode Island General
label: BODY

text: Laws 6-16-4 and 6-16-5, made applicable to this case by code § 544(b)(1).  Counts I and
label: BODY

text: II seek the same result under code  § 548.  The movants argue the fraud theories
label: BODY

text: advanced by the plaintiff in those counts are barred by the applicable statutes of limitations.
label: BODY

text: The Committee responds that the statutes of limitations were equitably tolled.  The movants
label: BODY

text: counter that the factual predicate for equitable tolling either was not alleged or not available
label: BODY

text: as a matter of law.
label: BODY

text: The movants contend that while the Rhode Island statute of limitations specifically
label: BODY

text: recognizes the applicability of equitable tolling in the context of actual fraud, it is silent as
label: BODY

text: to constructive fraud.  See February 27, 2003 hearing record at 11:36.  That argument
label: BODY

text: ignores Rhode Island General Law § 9-1-20, which provides that if any cause of action,
label: BODY

text: e.g., for actual or constructive fraud, is concealed, the limitation period will not begin to
label: BODY

text: 3Rhode Island General Law § 9-1-20 provides “if any person, liable to an action by
label: BODY

text: another, shall fraudulently, by actual misrepresentation, conceal from him or her the
label: BODY

text: existence of the cause of action, the cause of action shall be deemed to accrue against the
label: BODY

text: person so liable at the time when the person entitled to sue thereon shall first discover its
label: BODY

text: existence.”
label: BODY

text: 4The movants assert that as the sole owner and shareholder of the debtor, Charles
label: BODY

text: E. Bradley’s knowledge of the scheme should be imputed to the debtor under principles of
label: BODY

text: agency.  That result is not warranted in the context of a motion to dismiss, because
label: BODY

text: Bradley’s interest was arguably adverse to the debtor.  See, e.g., In re Candor Diamond
label: BODY

text: Corp., 76 B.R. 342, 350-1 (Bankr. S.D.N.Y. 1987).  See also February 27, 2003 hearing
label: BODY

text: record at 12:12.
label: BODY

text: 5Section 548 provides:
label: BODY

text: (a)(1) The trustee may avoid any transfer of an interest of the debtor in property, or
label: BODY

text: any obligation incurred by the debtor, that was made or incurred on or within one
label: BODY

text: year before the date of the filing of the petition, if the debtor voluntarily or
label: BODY

text: involuntarily–
label: BODY

text: (A) made such transfer or incurred such obligation with actual intent to hinder, delay,
label: BODY

text: or defraud any entity to which the debtor was or became, on or after the date that
label: BODY

text: such transfer was made or such obligation was incurred, indebted; or
label: BODY

text: (B)(i) received less than a reasonably equivalent value in exchange for such
label: BODY

text: transfer or obligation; and
label: BODY

text: (ii)
label: BODY

text: (I) was insolvent on the date that such transfer was made or such obligation
label: BODY

text: was incurred, or became insolvent as a result of such transfer or obligation;
label: BODY

text: (II) was engaged in business or a transaction, or was about to engage in
label: BODY

text: business or a transaction, for which any property remaining with the debtor
label: BODY

text: accrue until the cause of action has been discovered.3   See Waters v. Salt Disney World
label: BODY

text: Here, Counts I and II allege that Pardee and Sutro concealed certain facts, had
label: BODY

text: actual or constructive knowledge of other facts, and participated in a scheme to deplete the
label: BODY

text: debtor’s assets.  See Complaint at ¶¶ 6, 9, 33, 34, 37, 47, 52, 54-58, incorporated into
label: BODY

text: Count I by ¶ 72 and Count II by ¶ 80.  The Committee has alleged that it “did not discover
label: BODY

text: nor could [it] have discovered with reasonable diligence the facts giving rise to this
label: BODY

text: Complaint any earlier than one year prior to the date [it was filed].” Complaint at ¶2.4
label: BODY

text: The movants argue that  code  § 548  provides a fixed one year window within which
label: BODY

text: a fraudulent transfer must have occurred to avoid the transfer.5  As the Committee correctly
label: BODY

text: was an unreasonably small capital; or
label: BODY

text: (III) intended to incur, or believed that the debtor would incur, debts that
label: BODY

text: would be beyond the debtor's ability to pay as such debts matured.
label: BODY

text: It is undisputed that the transfers at issue occurred more than one year before the petition
label: BODY

text: date.
label: BODY

text: 6Movants’ reliance on Hassett v. Zimmerman (In re O.P.M. Leasing Services, Inc.)
label: BODY

text: 32 B.R. 199 (Bankr. S.D.N.Y. 1983) for the proposition that the lookback provision in §548
label: BODY

text: is inelastic, is misplaced since that case did not involve an issue of equitable tolling.  See
label: BODY

text: Sutro Memorandum in Support of Motion to Dismiss at 4 and Feburary 27, 2003 hearing
label: BODY

text: record at 12:31:50.
label: BODY

text: observes, however, the doctrine of equitable tolling is generally read into every federal
label: BODY

text: statute, unless Congress expressly provides to the contrary in clear and unambiguous
label: BODY

text: language.
label: BODY

text: It is hornbook law that limitations periods are customarily subject to equitable
label: BODY

text: tolling . . . Congress must be presumed to draft limitations periods in light of
label: BODY

text: this background principle. That is doubly true when it is enacting limitations
label: BODY

text: periods to be applied by bankruptcy courts, which are courts of equity and
label: BODY

text: apply the principles and rules of equity jurisprudence.
label: BODY

text: Young v. United States, __ U.S.__, 122 S.Ct. 1036, 1039 (2002) (internal citations, ellipses
label: BODY

text: and quotation marks omitted);  Atlantic City Elec. Co. v. General Elec. Co., 312 F.2d 236,
label: BODY

text: Under the doctrine of wrongful concealment, “the statute of limitations will be tolled
label: BODY

text: if the plaintiff proves three elements: (1) wrongful concealment by the defendant, (2) which
label: BODY

text: prevented the plaintiff's discovery of the nature of the claim within the limitations period,
label: BODY

text: and (3) due diligence in pursuing discovery of the claim.” Butala v. Agashiwala, 916
label: BODY

text: F.Supp. 314, 319 (S.D.N.Y.1996) (cited in G-I Holdings v. Baron & Budd, 238 F.Supp.2d.
label: BODY

text: As noted, the Committee has alleged in Counts I and II that the movants engaged
label: BODY

text: in a systematic course of conduct which thwarted its discovery of the instant causes of
label: BODY

text: action. See Complaint at ¶¶ 6, 9, 33, 34, 37, 47, 52, 54-58, as incorporated by ¶¶72 and
label: BODY

text: 80.  Accepting those material allegations and construing them in the Committee’s favor, as
label: BODY

text: required in this analysis, see supra at 3, the motion to dismiss Counts I and II must be
label: BODY

text: denied.
label: BODY

text: 7Without requisite standing, the court lacks subject matter jurisdiction and the unjust
label: BODY

text: enrichment count must be dismissed pursuant to Rule 12(b)(1), F.R.Civ.P. See, e.g.,
label: BODY

text: Faibish v. University of Minnesota, 304 F.3d 797, 800 (8th Cir. 2002).
label: BODY

text: Rule 12(b)(1) motion to dismiss Count VIII
label: HH1

text: The movants contend that the Committee lacks standing to bring Count VIII (unjust
label: BODY

text: enrichment) because it alleges only that creditors have been harmed and not the debtor.7
label: BODY

text: See Complaint at ¶¶111-115.  Again, construing that count in the Committee’s favor, it
label: BODY

text: plainly alleges that the debtor has been harmed by the movants’ conduct, see Complaint
label: BODY

text: at ¶¶1, 65, 70.  Indeed, as a remedy, Count VIII seeks the imposition of a constructive trust
label: BODY

text: “for the benefit of the debtor’s estate.” Id. at ¶115 (emphasis added).
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, the motions to dismiss are DENIED, and it is
label: BODY

text: SO ORDERED.
label: BODY

text: Dated at Bridgeport, CT this 9th of April, 2003.
